H0.text: Their leaves are where plants take in air.

H1.text: Their flowers are where plants take in air.

H2.text: Their stems are where plants take in air.

H3.text: Their roots are the part of plants where they take in air.

A4.text: the majority of those are found in specially adapted structures called leaves

A5.text: Certain species adapted to conditions of strong sunlight and aridity, such as many Euphorbia and cactus species, have their main photosynthetic organs in their stems

A6.text: Specialised structures (pneumatophores, aerial roots) permit gas exchange where soil oxygen is limited, enabling respiration in mangroves and other hydrophytes.

A7.text: In some plants like Avicennia the erect roots have a large number of breathing pores for exchange of gases.
